intro: Helianthella gypsophila, commonly known as the gypsum sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble sunflowers. The plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, particularly in gypsum soils, which provide its unique habitat. It produces small, yellow to orange flowers that bloom in the spring and summer months. Helianthella gypsophila is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in its native range.
